item.title: Private notes in a Microsoft work environment
item.description:
If your workplace uses Microsoft 365 and doesn't let you install software for storing encrypted notes or passwords, here's a tip: use OneNote to password-protect sensitive information

OneNote keyboard shortcuts make it convenient, too, to lock and unlock notes very quickly.

But remember: if you forget your password, you'll lose your information. The same goes for protecting Excel or Word documents with passwords.

item.title: Windows Clipboard Time Machine
item.description:
On Windows, you can view the history of what you've copied to your clipboard by pressing the Windows key plus the V key. You can then recopy anything from that history.

You might need to enable the feature, though, in Settings > System > Clipboard.

item.title: PowerToys: Batman utility belt for Windows
item.description:
Microsoft PowerToys is a collection of super handy utilities for Windows, where "super handy" means "Why don't these come with Windows by default?".

These are some of my favourite PowerToys:

-Image Resizer: Via a right click in File Explorer.

-PowerRename: Easy file renaming via File Explorer.

-Color Picker: Like Digital Colour Meter on MacOS

-Keyboard Manager: Create your own system-wide shortcuts; eg, for volume and media playback on keyboards that lack dedicated buttons.

item.title: LinkedIn Learning: often free with a library card
item.description:
First tech tip: Many public libraries provide access to LinkedIn Learning for free, and some of these libraries can be joined online. For example, in Australia:

  • Victoria: Yarra Plenty Regional Library
  • South Australia: Libraries SA
  • New South Wales: Wollongong City Libraries
  • Queensland: State Library

A downside is that you don't get certificates with your name on them.

Still, a saving of AUD$50 per month.
